comments.body: Can we keep one signature that accepts strings perhaps, and just map into this one?

The String based flow would require additional data to add the attributes so it would need to add those to the flow somehow. This would be possible by adding a second flow stage that maps the request to request with provided attributes, but the attribute set would need to be added to the signature, adding another 6 methods to the java api to support attributes with and without settings.
I could create a `simple(queueUrl: String, settings: SqsSinkSettings, sqsClient: AmazonSQSAsync): Flow[String, Result, Future[Done]]` maybe?
Why couldn't it just do `.map(new SendMessageRequest(queueUrl, _)).via(...)`, isn't that exactly what the original implementation did?

The original created and sent the `SendMessageRequest` inside the `SqsFlowStage` which was why I couldn't just add a new part to do the conversion.

It would be simple to add for the `ScalaDsl` but as I mentioned the `JavaDsl` gets very unwieldy if we want to support the various parameter combinations.
Ah, ok, fair enough skip it then, it is easy enough for users to create themselves even if it had been nice not to break existing code
I agree, I couldn't find a sane way to not break old code without totally reimplementing the internals of the flow, so thought this was the more suitable and future flexible solution.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +24,28 @@  def create(queueUrl: String,
             settings: SqsSinkSettings,
             sqsClient: AmazonSQSAsync): Flow[SendMessageRequest, Result, NotUsed] =
    scaladsl.SqsFlow.apply(queueUrl, settings)(sqsClient).asJava
